fields.description:
* Rename 'Changes' to 'Commits' since 'Changes' does not describe changes when running a build from a specific revision
** Update for result summary 'changes' section
** Update result summary 'changes' tab and tab name
* This is more inline with Stash terminology. Yay for consistency.
fields.summary: Rename 'Changes' to 'Commits'

fields.description:
See https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/182034/bamboo-ssh-task-logs-are-missing-line-breaks

It's quite a hassle because while for some programs where I have source for, I can change the output to be carriage returns, or \r\n; but there are things where I have no source control on and the output is simply horrendous.

Could we have some sort of line-ending detection please?
fields.summary: SSH Tasks do not respect newlines as line breaks

fields.description: When we have a plan branch with repository overridden  to a different location, it will get disabled, because branch detection runs against a different repository, with a different set of branches.
fields.summary: Bamboo's automatic branch management works on branches from unrelated repositories

fields.description:
It seems like the backup failed because the build expiry was running at the same time. Perhaps, pausing the build expiry if the backup is running?

Because the backup failed I got an error message on the main screen telling me it failed, but I cannot remove it in either Firefox nor Chrome. Attached is what it looks like.

It seems like a restart is the only way I could clear it up. I even tried clicking everywhere inside and outside of that yellow box, but it wouldn't work.
fields.summary: Backup failure warning is stuck on screen.

fields.description:
Ideally when the authentication of repositories are set to none in cases when it is required, the build should fail with the message " Authentication failed". This is however not the case in Bamboo 5.0

*Steps to reproduce*
# Create a git repository with authentication set to username/password
# Enter a valid credentials
# Run some builds to ensure that the config are correct.
# Edit the repository configuration and set the authentication to *None*

Withe that, we will expect that the build fails but it still goes fine to use the stored credentials in step 2. This is replicated in Bamboo 5.x only. Here is a build logs with verbose logs checked in the repository config:
{noformat}
simple	02-Aug-2013 21:16:55	Build TESTA - TSTA - Default Job #3 (TESTA-TSTA-JOB1-3) started building on agent Default Agent
simple	02-Aug-2013 21:16:55	Build working directory is D:\atlassian\BAMBOO\atlassian-bamboo-5.0.1\HOME\xml-data\build-dir\TESTA-TSTA-JOB1

simple	02-Aug-2013 21:16:55	'C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\cmd\git.exe' log -1 --encoding=UTF-8 --format=%H HEAD
simple	02-Aug-2013 21:16:55	Fetching 'refs/heads/master' from 'https://bitbucket.org/sultanmaiyaki/parentmodule.git'.

simple	02-Aug-2013 21:16:59	Build TESTA-TSTA-JOB1-3 completed.
simple	02-Aug-2013 21:16:59	Running on server: post build plugin 'NCover Results Collector'

*Workaround*
You will have to alter or clear the credentials in the repository configuration first before setting it to none.

*Second Workaround if the above does not work*
1. Make sure all your caches, cookies and browser history is successfully deleted.
2. Remove the user name and password for the problematic plan, set the authentication type to None and save the changes.
3. Clone the plan for which you are experiencing this issue.
4. In the cloned plan, go under the repositories tab, add a new repository, fill in all the information same as the default/existing repository and select *None* for authentication type. Save this new repository. 
5. Delete the old repository that was not saving the changes correctly.
6. Tasks should now switch to use the new repository, but double check this by selecting the task and checking the "Source Code Checkout" task.
fields.summary: Repository credentials are stored and used even when authentication is set to None

fields.description:
I have plan variables to store the major and minor versions separately, as our deploy scripts handle major and minor upgrades differently, and the variables only seem to resolve to their value half of the time when generating a new release.  Funny thing is, the variables always seem to work right when I click preview on the Release Versioning page.

To reproduce, add a variable to plan, say build.foobar = works, run the plan and then attempt to make a release out of it using the variable $\{bamboo.build.foobar\} in the release name.  It will work in the preview, but it will frequently not work when generating the release.  As far as I can tell there is nothing different happening when it works vs. when it doesn't.
fields.summary: Custom plan variables do not seem to resolve to their values consistently when generating a release

See example below:

This is useful when using Deployments where you will then codesign and package apps for Ad Hoc, In House and App Store distribution with different provisioning profiles.

fields.description:
I was cloning the AutoDeploy JDOG plan so I could deploy stuff to my servers.
I *left* the Enable Plan checked (which is IMO a bad default) and the plan kicked off before I had any opportunity to change it - first of all change the target server.

It was a major WTF for me - why would it kick off immediately if the original plan was a scheduled one, due to be run in 13 hours.

Fortunately the plan got stuck in the queue so I managed to stop it before it brought down JDOG, but I was seconds from causing MUO.

Please consider making "reducing WTF" a priority in next Bamboo release ;-)
fields.summary: Please add a warning that if I Enable Plan that I clone it will be kicked off immediately

fields.description:
When we try to run a customized build to build a particular revision, the build is queued for a long time depending on the settings of the quite period configuration. You will receive this kind of info in the logs:
{code}
2013-07-31 04:30:58,494 INFO [qtp35496097-165] [AccessLogFilter] admin POST http://localhost:1050/bamboo50/ajax/runParametrisedManualBuild.action 119074kb
2013-07-31 04:30:58,789 INFO [3-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-6-thread-5] [SvnRepository] Collecting changes for 'TESTA-SVN' on path 'https://sultan-pc/svn/junit/trunk' from version 4 to 4
2013-07-31 04:30:58,796 INFO [3-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-6-thread-5] [DefaultChangeDetectionManager] : Found one change for plan 'TESTA-SVN', waiting 10 seconds to see if there are any more... (one retry remaining)
{code}

Bamboo should not be waiting for commits if it a customized build of a subversion repository as the case with other repo types like Git.
fields.summary: Bamboo should ignore the subversion quite period in repository configuration if running a customized build

fields.description:
Currently, the test resources that are used in AMPS Bamboo plugin contain only one "admin" user.

This is unlikely an ideal initial set up for most plugin developers.

I would propose to make the following changes to the test resources:
* add a new 'sysadmin' user that has system administrator permission
* change the current 'admin' user to have only administrator permission (revoke the system administrator permission)
* add a new non-admin user 'joe' or 'fred'.

Ideally the changes mentioned above are the same across all product's test resources to make it easier to write tests for cross-product plugin.
fields.summary: Generate more test data in test resources

* bamboo-admin
* bambo-restricted-admin
* bamboo-user
Attempting to add the _bamboo-restricted-admin_ group:
!add_group.png|thumbnail!
...yields the following:
!add_group_fail.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: IncorrectResultSizeDataAccessException While Adding Group/User To Global Permissions

fields.description:
We use 2 stages in our plan. Each creates it's own artifact. The first one runs it's tasks and creates an artifact once it has finished successfully. This artifact is then used by the second plan (as Artifact dependency).

The first Stage's plan definition uses the copy pattern "htdocs/" (which is the same as "htdocs/**" in ant, which means "htdocs recursively"). This does not copy those "dead" symlinks. They are just missing when we have a look into that build-dir of the second stage.
Symlinks which resolve OK in build environment are also not exported as symlinks, but instead as files, containing the symlink's destination file's content, which also is not OK, since it alters what is exported as artifact, also.

Symlinks should be respected when building the artifacts as any normal files are. And not (silently) skipped.
fields.summary: Bamboo artifacts do not respect symlinks

fields.description:
Using Bamboo 5.0, we configured the new feature "Deployments" for our projects. This divide in "Build" and "Deploy" is great, but we cannot open the Log of ran Deployments.

We go the following clickpath once the deploy has finished with status "success":

Plan > Deployments > Environment > View details (Next to the successfull deployment)

The problem is, that this showes the loadspinner and the Text "Loading log entries…" forever without displaying it, no matter how long we wait.
Please find a screenshot of this attached.
fields.summary: Cannot load Log of Deployments

fields.description:
We have only had perforce client installed on one of our remote agent server not local bamboo server. Even though, we added agent specific capability for perforce, but when trying to configure a source repository for a plan, it still says "You must first have the perforce client executable defined as a server capability".

Do we have to have perforce client installed on local bamboo server?
fields.summary: Cannot add perforce as source repository as perforce is only installed on remote agent server
Release notes for 5.0.1

fields.description:
In 4.3.3: When using the filter on the dashboard, if there arr around 25 projects already added, adding additional projects makes an exception error showing up in the UI about exceeding 255 character limit. 
In 5.0: Same error message showed up on my first try adding 25 projects to the filter.
If there is any limit to the number of projects that can be selected in the filter, we should mention this some where in the UI.

fields.summary: 500 Exception when using the dashboard filter

fields.description:
Generate notification to user for build that is stopped from progressing for a long time.

This would be great to notify user if the build is actually stopped due to certain error.
fields.summary: Generate notification to user for build that is stopped from progressing for a long time

fields.description:
Our user base for Bamboo is steadily growing however we have some difficulties with permissions. 

Users want to copy existing plans that show our best practice however in order for them to have permissions to see how other teams have set things up (i.e. being able to view scripts and other task configurations) they have to have permissions that are high enough that they could start builds or even modify the configuration. Perhaps I've misunderstood the current permissions but I can't see how this can be done.

What I would like is a new permission that I could give to users or groups that would allow them to inspect another projects configuration, but they cannot trigger manual builds or edit anything in the configuration.

Thanks and keep up the good work!
fields.summary: New permission type: View configuration without being able to trigger or edit.

fields.description: The stash Bamboo plugin accept only basic access or a combination of basic access with other modes such as trusted app and OAUTH. Make it possible for it to accept configuration of either trusted or OAUTH
fields.summary: Make Stash Bamboo Plugin use Trusted Applications or OAUTH

fields.description:
* Our repository variables are highly inconsistent
* We should just use the format of bamboo.repository for all repository variables, regardless of build and deployment. Lets worry about how this would work when deployments have change detection later.
* We should keep all existing variable names. The new ones will replace them.

For any repositories that have these attributes, we need to add where applicable:
* bamboo.repository.<position>.name
* bamboo.repository.<position>.branch
* bamboo.repository.<position>.url
* bamboo.repository.<position>.username
* bamboo.repository.<position>.revision
* bamboo.repository.<position>.type
* bamboo.repository.<position>.revision.previous

The default repository should always be addressable with:
* bamboo.repository.name
* bamboo.repository.branch
* bamboo.repository.url
* bamboo.repository.username
* bamboo.repository.revision
* bamboo.repository.type
* bamboo.repository.revision.previous

These would replace:
* bamboo.repository.hg.branch
* bamboo.repository.git.branch
* bamboo.repository.git.repositoryUrl
* bamboo.repository.hg.repositoryUrl
* bamboo.repository.hg.username
* bamboo.repository.git.username
* bamboo.custom.p4.username
* bamboo.custom.svn.username
* bamboo.custom.svn.revision.number
* bamboo.repository.previous.revision.number
* bamboo.repository.revision.number
* bamboo.repository.branch.name

We would need to mark these variables as deprecated in the docs.
fields.summary: Fix inconsistent repository variables

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Add two different source repositories for a plan that are both configured correctly
2. Make only one task that uses one of these repositories
3. Build runs successfully
4. Now add a third plan repository that is NOT configured correctly
5. Build fails even though the mis-configured repository is not even used by any tasks. 

Testing for this in 4.4.5 gave me the same result. 
Screenshots are in order.
fields.summary: Build should not fail if the repository is not used by any tasks in the Plan

fields.description:
I was able to reduce the error to a single line in configureEnvironmentTasks.ftl.  

${webResourceManager.requireResourcesForContext("ace.editor")}

When requiring this resource the browser will fail with a javascript error also failing most of the functionality of the page.

TypeError: ace.define(...) is not a function
 
If I remove the line 

${webResourceManager.requireResourcesForContext("ace.editor")}

from configureEnvironmentTasks.ftl the page loads correctly and the normal editing functionality of the tasks is available (not sure what I am not losing without the inclusion).

I have a feeling there is something odd with my environment but cannot quite pin it down.

This also occurs when editing a Plan's Job's tasks.
fields.summary: Editing Deployment Project Tasks Has Javascript Error

fields.description:
In Bamboo 4.4.5, when a user is the plan admin, with view, edit and admin permissions, he can access the permissions tab under plan configuration. In Bamboo 5.0 an "Access Denied" error is showing up when the plan admin user, with the exact same permissions tries to access this page.

If this is a problem please have it fixed. 

If this is on purpose and the plan admin should not have access to the permissions tab, why is the tab even available for him to be selected? Wouldn't is be better to hide this option for users who should not have access to it similar to how there is no "Administration" in the menus or on the dashboard for them? (The "Type" should change to an improvement request if this is the case).
fields.summary: Access denied for plan admin on the permission tab

fields.description:
Running [unit] tests from ANT/command line is challenging, it requires many steps to be setup before unit tests can even be run. Unfortunately, we don't have any guidelines for implementing this and making it work with Bamboo.

Please provide specific steps/guide to get tests running on a headless system on the bamboo server.
fields.summary: Provide documentation on setting up Bamboo tests for Android projects

fields.description:
It would be awesome to be able to schedule a "once-off" deployment for a specific build at a specific date and time to a specific environment, for instance: 

We know in advance which version we want to deploy, and we do production deployments late at night because that is when our applications will be the least busy. Currently we need someone to be awake just to press the "deploy" button. 

It would be nice to be able to configure a trigger to do this, or alternatively be able to set a "delayed" date & time to execute the deployment when clicking "Deploy".
fields.summary: Allow deployments at a specific date & time

fields.description:
Hi,

we are using a seperate SVN branch for each software release.
Therefore it would be great if if would be possible to select the branch for deployment on every release.

For example.
Release: V1.0.0 => SVN Branch: /branches/V1.0.0
Release: V1.2.0 => SVN Branch: /branches/V1.2.0
fields.summary: Deplayment: Allow branch selection for each release.

fields.description: MSBuild task should be made compatible with deployment projects
fields.summary: Support msbuild task in deployment projects

fields.description: I followed a link by clicking on the label in a plan. It navigated to [hostname]/browse/label/[labelName]. It doesn't seem to provide a feed for current or past builds.
fields.summary: Build Feed by Label Not Working

fields.description:
In JUnit parser the option "Specify custom results directories" seems to be handling wrong the file extensions.
My test harness generates the reports in \*.nxml files. I tried setting the  "Specify custom results directories" option to \*\*/test-results/\*.nxml and it failed with:
{code}
24-Jul-2013 13:56:29	Starting task 'Get xml test results' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.testresultparser:task.testresultparser.junit'
24-Jul-2013 13:56:29	Parsing test results...
24-Jul-2013 13:56:29	Failing task since test cases were expected but none were found.
24-Jul-2013 13:56:29	Finished task 'Get xml test results'
{code}

However, if I rename my files to .xml and set the option to \*\*/test-results/\*.xml it works perfectly.

Am I missing something or is just the JUnit parser who does not handle extensions different than XML?
fields.summary: JUnit Parser does not open file with extensions different from .xml

fields.description:
Currently we have two pages for variables:
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Using+global,+plan+or+build-specific+variables
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Variables+for+deployment+environments

We should have one page that, in darkness, bind them.

We are also deprecating a bunch of variables in 5.1 for repositories and introducing a consistent set of new variables that will replace them.

When we create the One Page for all variables, we should have a section on repository variables that applies to both deployment and build variables. See BAM-13522.

An general explanation will be needed on how variables can be used as a system environment variable.
fields.summary: One variable page to rule them all

fields.description:
At the moment, the metadata REST API expansion does not show the build variables. The following URL only provides the metadata: URL/rest/api/latest/result/TESTA-TSTA-JOB1-5?expand=metadata I will propose to have another expansion point "variables" so that we can use the URL URL/rest/api/latest/result/TESTA-TSTA-JOB1-5?expand=variables to expose the build variables. 

This is originally raised from https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/191160/how-do-i-read-bamboo-custom-variables-via-the-rest-api
fields.summary: Expose the build variables via the REST API

fields.description:
This has been tested to affect instances running on openjdk-1.7 where the *wrapper.java.command=java* specified in conf/wrapper.conf does not resolve to a 64 bit version and hence the startup script picks the wrong 32bit architecture which will fail to start Bamboo.

in the start-bamboo script it run the command
{code}
# Decide on the wrapper binary to use.
javaCommand=$(grep wrapper.java.command $WRAPPER_CONF | sed s/.*=//)
if file $(which $javaCommand) | grep -q x86.64 ; then #it's x86_64 or x86-64
	wrapperArch=64
	wrapperArchFallback=32
else
	wrapperArch=32
	wrapperArchFallback=64
fi
{code}

*Workaround*
* delete the wrapper/wrapper-linux-x86-32 so that it will fallback to the 64 version
* Edit the {{conf/wrapper.conf}} file to point to the exact location of java. Something like: *wrapper.java.command=/usr/local/java/jdk1.7.0_17/bin/java*
fields.summary: Start-Bamboo script is not finding the correct architecture due to use of wrong java version

fields.description:

fields.description:

fields.description:
We have 3 Stages in a Plan:
1) checkout source code
2) compile
3) test

We generate Artifact with needed files/scripts in the First Job (Checkout), and share it to second and third ones.

Second and Third Stage get files from Artifact and these files/scripts Do Not Have executable bits.

Our compile and test Stages are strongly depend on this scripts, so we would like to have executable bits preserved.
fields.summary: Artifacts sharing do not preserve executable bits on Linux

fields.description: * Chase up with Matty for info graphics
fields.summary: Publish stages guide
Small docs improvements

fields.description:
It's currently not possible to trigger a deployment project from a stage of a plan. Deployment projects can be triggered upon completion of a plan but if, for example, there is a plan with two stages when the second stage is manual, there is no way to trigger the deployment when the second stage completes. 

One solution can be breaking the stages into two different plans and passing artifacts to the second plan, or setting it as a child plan of the first plan if the manual run can be converted into an automated process but this is not the best or easiest solution.
fields.summary: REST API for deployments

fields.description:
In a minimalistic environment with 3 local agents I am experiencing the following hindering issue:

# All 3 local compatible agents are idling.
# A plan is started manually.
# It takes way too long for plan to transition from "queued" to "running" state. 1, 2 even 3 minutes are rather frequent.

Described situation was not apparent on previous Bamboo 4.4.5 release. I can remember queue processing was typically a matter of seconds, 1 minute maximum. Not anymore.
fields.summary: Plan is queued for running way too long without obvious reason

fields.description: At the moment, deployment environments can be run either by agents at run time that satisfy the capabilities defined by the tasks or through dedicated agents. It will be helpful if we can manually add requirements to the environments similar to the build jobs so that we don`t end up marking the agent as "DEDICATED"
fields.summary: Ability to add requirements to deployment environments

fields.description:
*steps to reproduce*
# Start a new instance from the wrapper using the command *start-bamboo start*
# The instance will be started fine with a pid generated. This can be verified with a pid file created in the wrapper directory
# When we run the command *start-bamboo status*, it removes the pid and throws a message that Bamboo was not running. The same behavior is experienced if you run the *start-bamboo stop* command rather than the status where the pid will be removed.

The issue here is that the instance will still be running despite the removed pid and even killing the process will end up spinning another instance. You will have to kill the process for a random number of times. This has been tested with OpenJDK 1.7 and Oracle JDK 1.6 and 1.7

See screenshot
fields.summary: wrapper start and stop commands acting weirdly in Bamboo 5

The entire page is refreshed  every time a log entry comes back from the remote agent instead of just the live logs getting updated. 

Please check the attached screenshot, the log in the UI is still being generated while the TEST1-TEST-15 is already complete.

fields.description:
There's a wide variety of tools that may be in use at this point for building/testing in various languages or with various frameworks; without explicitly building a plugin for Bamboo that enables the .ftl and BuildTask options to return tests, there's no way to easily get test results to display inline in Bamboo without some extreme hackiness (an Ant script that simply make a call out to a Node executable, for instance).

As a common denominator, commands and scripts should be able to specify that they have the ability to return tests that Bamboo would be able to interpret.

Possibly workable as "TestableCommand" and "TestableScript" build task types to avoid issues with the current Command and Script tasks?
fields.summary: Command and Script build tasks should enable test results to be returned

fields.description:
Hi Atlassians, 

i´m not sure if this is a missing feature, or if i´m just to stupid to find the right configuration.

I have set up a plan with two stages. In the first stage the source code is checked out, build and tested. The result is a shared artifact with the results of the build. In the second stage, i download the artifact and copy it to a remote server via a script. For the master-branch this works fine.

Then i have configured branch-plans. But when i build a branch in the second stage of the branch-plan not the artifact created during the first stage is downloaded but the artifact created in the last run of the master-build-plan (=the last build of the master-branch). In the log i can see this happening:

19-Jul-2013 13:07:43 	Build GeDok 5 - Gated Build - Refactoring_Tim - Deploy GeDok 5 #2 (DDEV-GB5-DEPLOY-2) started building on agent Default Agent
19-Jul-2013 13:07:44 	Build working directory is D:\Bamboo\xml-data\build-dir\DDEV-GB5-DEPLOY
19-Jul-2013 13:07:44 	Executing build GeDok 5 - Gated Build - Refactoring_Tim - Deploy GeDok 5 #2 (DDEV-GB5-DEPLOY-2)
19-Jul-2013 13:07:44 	Running pre-build action: Clover Grails PreBuild Action
19-Jul-2013 13:07:44 	Running pre-build action: VCS Version Collector
19-Jul-2013 13:07:44 	Starting task 'Build-Ergebnis laden' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloadertask'
19-Jul-2013 13:07:44 	Preparing to download plan result DDEV-GB-65 artifact: Shared artifact: [GeDok5_Gated_Files], pattern: [**/Gebit.GeDok.Launcher/bin/Debug/**]
19-Jul-2013 13:07:44 	Artifact [GeDok5_Gated_Files] downloaded successfully in 0s

GB5 refers to the branch-build (Gated build #5). The downloaded artifact is "DDEV-GB-65 artifact", which is the artifact created during the 65th run of the master-build-plan.

fields.description:
It's quite simple: in Script Task's configuration there's a new checkbox 'Run as Powershell script'.
If you check it the script is run with powershell instead of cmd.exe (the latter interprets .bat files)
Inline editor supports powershell syntax.

Under the hood, the following command is run:

powershell -ExecutionPolicy bypass -Command script_name [script_options]

However not all available shared repository will be displayed there. Github and Perforce for example will not be shown in that list. (Tested with SVN, Github, Bitbucket, Perforce, Git)

h4. Steps to replicate

fields.description:
We very often see situations when:
*  all EC2 slots are used and some (or even most) instances are idle but kept running until the end of the paid hour,
* some jobs are blocked in the queue because they need to run on EC2 on specific instances which are not running/not idle.

While I understand the need to optimise cost and starting speed, that causes long feedback loop.

Worse case scenario means a job can be stuck for more than 30 minutes with all EC2 agents being idle. Then the EC2 agent can take as much as 20mn to be started (spot instance bidding time + VM startup). So we create nearly an hour of wait time to save a few cents...

Please consider the following improvement to ease the pain for those corner cases:
IF all the EC2 slots are used
  AND there is a job in the queue that can only run in EC2
  AND no EC2 image currently running have the right requirements
THEN
  disable and kill an idle EC2 image

The exact algorithm for idle EC2 image selection is left as an exercise to the reader: Most represented type of idle images? Longest idle?
fields.summary: Avoid "starvation" for jobs pinned to EC2 images

fields.description:
Most other pieces of Bamboo, at this point, have granular on/off states; triggers remain one of the few places without.

The use case is a situation where there might be automated nightly builds under normal circumstances, but that at times need to be paused and only run manually. 

* Disabling the plan prevents manual execution
* Deleting the trigger means recreation down the road
* Adding a manual build stage is hacky

To be fair, in our situation, I believe Bamboo 5 deployment plans may solve our immediate issue, but filing the improvement request anyway since its a nice to have option.
fields.summary: Add Enable/Disable checkbox to Triggers

fields.description:
We use the $\{bamboo.repository.hg.*\} variables to invoke scripts on our plans.

But, our plans contain multiple repositories. Previously $\{bamboo.repository.hg.*\} referred to the default repository, which is the top one in the repository list for the plan.

After upgrading to bamboo 5.0, this is broken. First, all plans had their repository lists reordered alphabetically, which we manually fixed (unintentional upgrade script bug?).

After fixing $\{bamboo.repository.hg.repositoryUrl\} arbitrarily changes. On manual runs it appears to be the first (default) repo. On change triggered runs it appears to be the first alphabetically.

I don't know what the variable should point to, but it sure as hell shouldn't be non-deterministic. I can use plan variables to work around this, but really don't want to edit the 20 builds that rely on $\{bamboo.repository.hg.*\} working.
fields.summary: ${bamboo.repository.hg.*} are broken in bamboo 5.0

fields.description:
We had this task https://extranet-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/build/admin/edit/editBuildTasks.action?buildKey=CRUCHG-WOOF-JOB1 configured with the following variable:

* $\{bamboo.fisheye.zip.dir\} 
as the Destination path.

The logs made me believe that the expanded value was being used:

{code}
command	15-Jul-2013 15:00:07	Substituting variable: ${bamboo.fisheye.zip.dir} with tmp/fisheye-zip-dir
simple	15-Jul-2013 15:00:07	Starting task 'Download Artifact' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloadertask'
simple	15-Jul-2013 15:00:07	Preparing to download plan result CRUCHG-DEFAULT-868 artifact: Shared artifact: [FishEye Zip], pattern: [fisheye-*.zip] anchored at: [target/wac/]

However the expanded value was not being used by the Task.

Logging onto the agent showed that the task used the unsubstituted string as the path:

{code}

{code}

This should be a quick fix?

BTW - this task is kinda essential for Continuous Deployment for us! Great stuff!!

fields.description:
A Bamboo user of ours was recently running a task in Bamboo that executed an inline tcsh script (we have to use tcsh here for historical reasons before anyone links to http://www.faqs.org/faqs/unix-faq/shell/csh-whynot).

The script was
{code}exec tcsh -f $0 $*

foreach x (a b c)
  echo $x
end{code}

The output was simply
{code}a{code}

Investigation showed that adding a comment after the final line resulted in the correct output. However when adding just a carriage return on it's own to the script the faulty output was seen again. Looking at the script after a save, trailing empty lines have been stripped.

According to some of the developers here, files should always be saved with a trailing EOL as a number of gnu tools require it.

The workaround for this is trivial however so this is not a major issue but I thought it worth reporting.
fields.summary: Inline scripts are not saved with a final carriage return

fields.description:
Deployments are currently arranged in the order that they are created.

It would be nice to be able to rearrange deployments.

This would look much nicer in a situation where a deployment may only proceed if another succeeded (i.e. production deployed only if testing deployed).

Would potentially look something like this:
|| Environment || Status || Version ||
| Master | Deployed | 1.15 |
| QA | Deployed | 1.15 |
| Dogfood | Failed | 1.14 |
| Production | Deployed | 1.10 |

(shows that 1.14 was the last successful version that made it to dogfood, and 1.10 was the last successful version that made it to production)
fields.summary: Reorder environments on the deployments and project pages
